3555 Las Vegas Blvd S.
Las Vegas, NV 89109

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A male Ringed Teal duck has been missing since 12/09/2024. The keepers conducted several attempts to relocate the
duck however, at this time the keepers conclude the duck has escaped or possibly died. The ducks at this facility are
flight-restricted and are allowed to roam free within the outdoor housing facility.
Failure to conduct daily observations of this bird does not allow for accountability of the bird in the collection or for
monitoring changes in health status or injury, which may lead to animal death. Daily observation of all animals must be
performed to assess their health and well-being. A mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that
timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior and well-being is conveyed to the attending
veterinarian.
Correct from this day, 03/06/2025, forward.

There have been two incidents within the past year in which this facility handled its birds in a manner which posed a risk
of harm to the animal and to the public due to insufficient barriers between the animals and the public.
-On 01/18/2025, a member of the public was able pass through public barriers including bushes and a water-filled moat to
access the Flamingo Island, where 7 Chilean Flamingos are housed as well as several free-roaming waterfowl. According
to facility representatives based on video surveillance, the individual walked around the entire island for approximately 10-
15 minutes including through the group of flamingos. And records state during this event, “the flamingos were moving very
quickly trying to avoid her, running, slipping, sliding in the mud, jumping over large rocks to dodge her and falling all over
the place. Several times the flamingos were seen face planting into their shallow pond and on the dirt/grass areas.”
Following this incident, although the staff did not find any external injuries or wounds to the flamingos, records show they
were immediately found to be anxious, skittish, and acting unusual. The staff reported lots of flagging and alerting from
the group and pacing by one of the males. Overall, a majority of the flamingos continue to exhibit some abnormal and
anxious behaviors according to staff. Also noted was one Whistler duck which was observed to be limping on its right foot
following the incident.
-On 03/10/2024, a member of the public was able to access the Flamingo Island where a flock of 7 flamingos are housed.
Records show a morning keeper noticed that in the cave shelter were open containers, displaced items and supplies, and
some mirrors pulled down from the walls and onto the ground. According to the keepers, there were no physical injuries to
the flamingos observed following this incident, however they showed a decrease in appetite and evidence of stress and
anxiety including increased flagging, searching, and calling behaviors.
Ineffective barriers which allow the public to gain access to animal housing areas does not assure the safety of the public
or the animals. Members of the public may become injured if the animals become unexpectedly startled or stressed, and
the animals may experience severe behavioral stress, injury or death from encountering the public inside their enclosure.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safely of the
animals and the public.
Correct from this day, 03/06/2025, forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A male Ringed Teal duck has been missing since 12/09/2024. The keepers conducted several attempts to relocate the

performed to assess their health and well-being. A mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required so that 
timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior and well-being is conveyed to the attending 
veterinarian. 
 
Correct from this day, 03/06/2025, forward. 
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
There have been two incidents within the past year in which this facility handled its birds in a manner which posed a risk 
of harm to the animal and to the public due to insufficient barriers between the animals and the public. 
 
-On 01/18/2025, a member of the public was able pass through public barriers including bushes and a water-filled moat to

-On 03/10/2024, a member of the public was able to access the Flamingo Island where a flock of 7 flamingos are housed.

Ineffective barriers which allow the public to gain access to animal housing areas does not assure the safety of the public 
or the animals. Members of the public may become injured if the animals become unexpectedly startled or stressed, and 
the animals may experience severe behavioral stress, injury or death from encountering the public inside their enclosure. 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safely of the 
animals and the public. 
 
Correct from this day, 03/06/2025, forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
